screen.title: Getting your way around

summary.p: Collaboration is crucial to free software projects. Traditionally, it has been difficult for communities to exchange information if they use different tools.

Throughout this tour, you'll see how Launchpad's new approach solves the problems of collaboration on software projects. By bringing together information from different project-specific sources and helping communities to organise themselves into teams, Launchpad helps different projects to collaborate on common problems, such as bugs in shared code.
Let's start with finding your way around the interface.

screen.callout: You can always see which project you're currently working on in the top-left of the page.
Use the tabs to switch between Launchpad's applications.
The Actions menu gives you different options, depending on which application you're using.
You can find additional information in the expandable boxes below the Actions menu.

screen.title: Member details
screen.summary: Launchpad makes it easy to find out what work someone is involved in. Each individual's home page shows their team memberships, the projects that they're most active in and their contact details.
screen.callout: Knowing who you're working with is an important part of community building and may help you find people to collaborate with. Each Launchpad user can post a short description of themselves and a photo.
Launchpad shows you which projects a user is most active in and the Launchpad applications they've used for those projects.
Similarly, you can see all the teams that a person has joined.
It's important to be able to contact people you want to work with. Launchpad shows you how to contact them and where to find a wiki page with more information.

screen.title: Team management

summary.p: Strong communities are built on teams. Launchpad helps communities to develop rich structures, through the spontaneous creation of teams around projects and initiatives.

Anyone can create a team and you can use them just about anywhere that you'd use an individual: for example, as a member of another team, as a project's bug contact or to access a shared Bazaar branch.

screen.callout: Your team's description is an important way to let potential members know what the team plans to do and how it is organised.

You can choose from three membership policies for your team. Open membership means anyone can join, anyone can apply to a moderated team but a team administrator must approve their membership and restricted teams are invitation-only.
Teams can own teams and be a member of other teams. The row of small icons shows which other teams this team belongs to.
